M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: - M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 (custody modifications must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances and serve the child’s best interests).

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: - M.G.L. c. 208, § 31 (requiring determinations of custody and visitation to consider the welfare and best interests of the child).

*Schaffer v. Schaffer*, 72 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The standard for modification of a prior custody order, as articulated in *Schaffer v. Schaffer*, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 592 (2008), requires a showing of a material change in circumstances and the modification’s necessity to serve the child’s best interests.
*Schaffer v. Schaffer*, 72 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case involving Medicaid fraud and illegal prescribing by a physician; it does not involve family law, custody, or modification of custody orders. The text contains no discussion of standards for modifying prior custody orders or the best interests of a child. Therefore, it cannot serve as authority for the stated custody‑modification proposition.

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The Plaintiff asserts that Defendant's relocation and insistence on maintaining the current parenting schedule constitutes a material change in circumstances under Massachusetts case law, including *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Bouchard does not address relocation, parenting schedules, or what constitutes a material change in circumstances. It is a custody decision focused on the requirement that custody determinations be based on the child’s best interests and that the judge make adequate findings on relevant factors. It therefore does not establish or discuss the rule that a parent’s relocation plus insistence on the existing schedule is a material change in circumstances.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), the child’s best interests are the paramount concern in custody determinations and modifications.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that in removal and custody matters the child’s best interests are the paramount concern, and interprets the governing Massachusetts statutes (including c. 208) through that lens. The court explains that “upon cause shown” in the removal statute means removal must be in the child’s best interests and reiterates that, although the custodial parent’s interests are considered, the child’s best interests always remain paramount. This directly supports the proposition that best interests are the controlling consideration in custody determinations and related modifications.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … ‘unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

*Bliss v. Bliss*, 442 Mass. 598 (2004).proposition: Continued enforcement of the midweek parenting time would also interfere with Emma’s health, academic performance, and overall quality of life, contrary to the principles articulated in *Bliss v. Bliss*, 442 Mass. 598 (2004).
*Bliss v. Bliss*, 442 Mass. 598 (2004).support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is not Bliss v. Bliss at all, but Mole v. University of Massachusetts, a retaliation and §1983 employment case. It deals with causation standards in retaliation claims, not parenting time, child health, academics, or best‑interest principles in custody/visitation decisions. Accordingly, it cannot provide authority for the family‑law-based proposition about midweek parenting time harming a child’s well-being.
*Bliss v. Bliss*, 442 Mass. 598 (2004).relevant_excerpt: The excerpted text is entirely about Professor Mole’s retaliation and civil rights claims against the University of Massachusetts Medical Center and does not mention parenting time, child custody, or Bliss v. Bliss. It therefore contains no relevant passage supporting the stated proposition.

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: - Case law interpreting material change in circumstances and best interests standard, including:
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses both the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ requirement for custody modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and how that standard relates to the child’s best interests. It holds that relocation alone (and a court-imposed temporary change in custody) do not constitute the requisite material change and reiterates that any modification must be necessary in the child’s best interests, elaborating on the best interests analysis in the removal context as well. Thus it is good authority for the proposition cited.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: - Case law interpreting material change in circumstances and best interests standard, including:
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case does discuss and apply the ‘best interests of the child’ standard in detail, but it does not meaningfully interpret or apply the ‘material/substantial change in circumstances’ standard. The court explicitly declines to reach the father’s argument that a substantial-change standard under § 20 should govern, finding that issue waived. Thus it is good authority on the best-interests standard in an initial/nonmarital custody context, but not on case law interpreting material change in circumstances.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: - Case law interpreting material change in circumstances and best interests standard, including:
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies and explicates the best interests standard in the adoption/care-and-protection context, including how to weigh competing placement plans, stability, sibling relationships, and expert testimony. It also discusses the (lack of) presumptions for particular placements and emphasizes the trial judge’s discretionary role, which is part of the ‘material change/best interests’ line of cases. While it does not use the specific phrase ‘material change in circumstances,’ it is clearly authority on how the best interests standard operates when considering a change from an existing foster placement to a different adoptive home.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’… Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support… so critical to his future development.”

*Hoard v. Hoard*, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 614.proposition: - Case law interpreting material change in circumstances and best interests standard, including:
*Hoard v. Hoard*, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 614.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns statutory interpretation of a municipal employee’s suspension under G.L. c. 268A, § 25, and related questions about pension eligibility and sick leave, not family law or custody. It does not discuss “material change in circumstances” or the “best interests” standard in any context, much less as standards for modifying custody or similar matters. Citing this case for that proposition would therefore be inaccurate and out of context.
*Hoard v. Hoard*, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 614.relevant_excerpt: “The threshold question is whether the complaint states an appropriate case for declaratory relief under G. L. c. 231A… Since there is no dispute concerning material facts but only a controversy concerning the interpretation of a statute, we decide the case on the merits… We turn to the provisions of G. L. c. 268A, § 25… We hold, therefore, that when the plaintiff’s term of office expired on December 31, 1979, his suspension under § 25 was terminated.”

*Cooper v. Cooper*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 51.proposition: - Case law interpreting material change in circumstances and best interests standard, including:
*Cooper v. Cooper*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 51.support_reasoning: The opinion is an alimony contempt enforcement case and does not analyze or apply the ‘material change in circumstances’ and ‘best interests of the child’ standards typically associated with modification of support or custody orders. Its discussion of modification is limited to construing a separation agreement’s contractual bar on future alimony reductions, not to articulating the general material-change/best-interests doctrines. It therefore is not proper authority for the proposition claimed.
*Cooper v. Cooper*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 51.relevant_excerpt: “4. The separation agreement. Phillip challenges the judge’s finding that the parties’ separation agreement prohibits him from any future modifications of alimony due to his employment. If the language of an agreement leaves any doubt as to its ordinary meaning, the court will ‘examine the subject matter of the agreement and the language employed, and will attempt to ascertain the objective sought to be accomplished by the parties.’… The Probate Court judge’s finding was reasonable. She read the language of their 1989 agreement to preclude future reduction based upon change in Phillip’s employment.”

*Charara v. Yatim*, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 32.proposition: - Case law interpreting material change in circumstances and best interests standard, including:
*Charara v. Yatim*, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 32.support_reasoning: The opinion is centrally about jurisdiction under the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act and whether to extend comity to a Lebanese Jaafarite custody decree. It contains an extended discussion of the Massachusetts ‘best interests of the child’ standard, but it does not involve a post‑judgment modification situation or interpret what constitutes a ‘material change in circumstances’—it is an initial custody determination in a divorce with an overlay of foreign-court comity. Thus it is not good authority for the specific proposition of ‘material change in circumstances and best interests standard,’ though it is solid authority for the content and child‑centered nature of the Massachusetts best interests test in general.
*Charara v. Yatim*, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 32.relevant_excerpt: “The best interests of a child is the overarching principle that governs custody disputes in the Commonwealth. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003)… What is in a child’s best interest depends upon the particular needs of the child, and is left largely to the discretion of the judge, who ‘may consider any factor pertinent to those interests.’ … The best interests analysis our courts employ is thus unlike the presumptive entitlement to custody that governed the custody proceeding in the Jaafarite Court in Lebanon.”
